nodes.name: Decision making process
nodes.text:
Decision making process

In the design phase, the focus shifts from theory to process. This is an important shift, as the form of the process will often pre-define the outcome. In this phase, the decision-making process is about identifying the key decision makers and ensuring the optimal outcomes are reached.

Key questions:

  • What is the form of the process, and over what timeline?
  • What structures can develop the institution?
  • What is the role of parliament?
  • How was the decision reached? At what level?

nodes.name: Stakeholder engagement
nodes.text:
Stakeholder engagment

In the design phase, stakeholder engagement is about identifying and influencing the key individuals and institutions that will shape the bank. Whereas in the casemaking phase much of the focus is on the political and public sphere, in the design phase this is much more about reaching out to those involved in the operational process of government.

  • What government departments and key institutions are affected by the design of the institution?
  • How will the decisions be narrowed down?
  • Who will make the key decisions on design?

nodes.name: Analytical support
nodes.text:
Analytical support

The key function of the analytical support in this phase is to solidify the business case for the Green Bank, by identifying the barriers and how the institution would resolve them, as well as the scale of capitalisation and finance to be used.

Key questions:

  • What barriers could the institution potentially address?
  • Why wouldn’t the finance gap be covered by existing companies or banks?
  • What form should the institution take (bank, fund etc.)? Why?
  • How should it most effectively be set up: governance, shareholders? What is the scale of the capitalization?
  • How should it most effectively be set up: governance, shareholders? What is the scale of the capitalization?
  • What should it use its financial resources to support?
  • How is the institution going to evolve?

nodes.name: Standards and frameworks
nodes.text:
Standards and frameworks

In the design phase, the standards and framework section helps to frame and contextualise the core functions of the new institution, as well as ensuring that the appropriate tools and standards are included in the bank from the outset.

Key questions:

  • What is the difference between a bank and a fund?

nodes.name: Design
nodes.text: The design phase starts once there is a buy-in that the current approach is insufficient for delivering the low carbon transition at the scale and speed required, and the policy makers agreed in principle to carry the idea forward. Here the institution goes from being a proposal to a concrete concept.
nodes.output:
Output

The design phase yields a series of outputs that lay the groundwork for the next “Establishment” phase.

In this (design) phase the institution starts taking shape, but there is still scope for improvement as the next phase will go into more detail on how to ensure the institution design is fit for purpose. For reference, a checklist the outputs of the design phase is presented below. We also include below the specific outputs generated in the UK case.

Establish the vision, governance and business model.

Determine how much green funding would be delivered within the existing policy framework.

Measure the significance of the market barriers.

Objectives and roles of the Green Bank, scope of operations.

  • Government vision
  • GIB Commission proposal
  • Environmental Audit Committee recommendations

The funding structure of the Green Bank (capitalization and leverage/borrowing powers).

Timeline for the establishment of the Green Bank.

Decide whether new legislation is needed.

Rationale for reform versus a new institution.

  • E3G's proposal
  • GIB Commission proposal
  • Environmental Audit Committee recommendations
